awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Medium: Collaborative Research: Generalized Caching-As-A-Service
awd_abstract_narration:
Caching has been a consistent tool of designers of high-performance, scalable computing systems, but	it has been deployed in so many ways that it can be difficiult to standardize and scale in cloud systems. This project elevates the use of caching in cloud-scale storage system to a "first-class citizen" by designing and implementing generalized Caching-as-a-Service (CaaS). CaaS defines transformative technology along four complementary dimensions. First, it defines a new abstraction and architecture for storage caches whereby storage stacks can easily embed lightweight CaaS clients within a distributed compute infrastructure. Second, CaaS formulates and theoretically analyzes distributed caching algorithms that operate within the CaaS service such that individual CaaS server nodes cooperate towards achieving globally optimal caching decisions. Third, the distributed CaaS clients and servers are co-designed to achieve strict durability and fault-tolerance in their implementations. And finally, all of the CaaS advancements are driven by insights generated from a detailed whole-system simulator that models the diverse cache devices, network configurations, and application demand.

The CaaS project supports a broad spectrum of applications that run in the private and public clouds. The CaaS project showcases these improvements via use cases in three important computing paradigms: Cloud, Big Data, and Deep Learning. The findings from the CaaS project create new educational content and research opportunities for undergraduates, Masters, and PhD students via exposition and involvement of these student groups within classroom projects and laboratory work. The outreach activities focus on the recruitment of under-represented students from minority groups in Computer Science for participation in the project. The outcomes of the CaaS project include open source software and public dissemination of research findings which help transition of the new technologies to practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: 


We developed Caching-as-a-Service (Caas), a generalized, fault-tolerant writeable storage caching service that is built to operate within data centers, provide the means to use cache capacity distributed across multiple nodes within the data center, and serve arbitrary storage workloads. While caches are being extensively used within data centers to accelerate storage accesses, CaaS addresses key limitations of existing solutions: (1) the inability to consolidate cache capacity across arbitrary workloads, (2) the inability to cache writes that are getting increasingly dominant in storage workloads, and (3) the inability to exercise quality-of-service awareness across workloads. CaaS separates storage access type from cache access type thereby providing generality across store types (block, file, KV, and object). CaaS implements durability via fault-tolerance, thereby providing the ability to cache writes without fear of data loss. And CaaS controls for latency and throughput across workloads via generating workload-specific miss-ratio curves and assigning cache capacity per workload accordingly. We evaluated CaaS using both synthetic and real-world workloads including over 300 storage traces drawn across 6 different open source storage workload collections from various types of organizations, academic and industry. Using Simulus, a generic python simulator for large-scale complex systems, we demonstrate that (1) using a CaaS over the network compares favorably to a local cache in terms of both aggregate cache hit-rate and cache latency, and (2) that CaaS provides support for meeting latency and throughput requirements for individual workloads which use the caching service. We will demonstrate via our ongoing implementation that CaaS will provide fault-tolerance in the presence of node failures within the CaaS cluster. 



Broader impact: 


Storage caches are widely used within both enterprise and cloud data centers. This project developed a new type of caching service that allows for more cost-efficient and performant use of the data centers storage cache resources. It does so while ensuring that the fundamental properties of data at rest within storage systems -- durability and persistence -- is not compromised. The contributions of this project thus impact computing infrastructure within modern data centers. 


This project supported two Hispanic PhD students, one female. It also supported four Hispanic undergraduate students, and two female undergraduate students throughout the project via REU supplements. 


Outcomes summary:


The findings from this project significantly advance the development of next-generation cloud and enterprise data centers by allowing for better resource utilization and cost-efficiency of storage systems while ensuring that the organization's data is never at risk.
